titleStmt.title: The Snail, the Tulip, and the Bee (Emblem 53)
Poem #118

encodingDesc.p: Transcriptions are encoded in TEI(P5)-conformant XML.

correction.p: Apparent errors are preserved and editorial corrections provided using SIC and CORR tags, but only where the editor conjectures that the original scribe or compositor would have recognized the instance as an error. For example, what according to modern usage is incorrect subject/verb agreement might have been deemed acceptable to a seventeenth-century scribe or compositor. All such instances are treated instead using the ORIG and REG tags. (See below.)

Corrections and annotations made within the scope of the original document either by its original authors, owners, and/or transcribers are noted using ADD tags. These annotations and may be futher explained within NOTE tags, as added by the editors of this digital edition, for display within the apparatus.

normalization.p: Original spellings, abbreviations, and orthography are preserved. Where in the manuscripts a character's status as majuscule or miniscule is ambiguous, the editor has silently chosen one or the other based on context and judgment (i.e., does not register such ambiguity in either the markup or the notes).

quotation.p: Original quotation marks, if any, are preserved.

glyph.glyphName: Handwritten 'ff' ligature, used in handwriting to represent modern F

listWit.witness: Transcription of manuscript: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.
Elemental edition: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.

rdg.seg: [Emblem 53]Unlike surrounding poems in the “Emblems” section, no number precedes this poem.

app.rdg:
The Snail, the Tulip, and the Bee
(Emblem 53)
AE TITLE

rdg.note: In these transcriptions we preserve as many details of the original material, textual, and graphic properties of Hester Pulter’s manuscript verse as we have found practical. Whenever possible, for instance, original spelling, punctuation, capitalization, lineation, insertions, deletions, alterations, spacing between words and lines, and indentation are all maintained; abbreviations and brevigraphs are not expanded; and superscript and subscript representations are retained. See full conventions for the transcriptions here.

The aim of the elemental edition is to make the poems accessible to the largest variety of readers, which involves modernizing spelling and punctuation as well as adding basic glosses. Spelling and punctuation reflect current standard American usage; punctuation highlights syntax which might otherwise be obscure. Outmoded but still familiar word forms (“thou,” “‘tis,” “hold’st”) are not modernized, and we do not modernize grammar when the sense remains legible. After a brief headnote aimed at offering a “way in” to the poem’s unique qualities and connections with other verse by Pulter or her contemporaries, the edition features a minimum of notes and interpretative framing to allow more immediate engagement with the poem. Glosses clarify synonyms or showcase various possible meanings in Pulter’s time. Other notes identify named people and places or clarify obscure material. We rely (without citation) primarily on the Oxford English Dictionary (OED), the Oxford Reference database, and the King James Version (KJV) of the Bible. When we rely on Alice Eardley’s edition of Pulter’s work, we cite her text generally (“Eardley”); other sources are cited in full. The result is an edition we consider a springboard for further work on Pulter’s poetry. See full conventions for this edition here.

We all know the cliché of the busy bee, but Pulter found in the bee an emblem not of virtuous industry but instead of overzealous curiosity, greed, and poor judgment. After praising “the active Amazonian maid” for her industriousness and herbalist know-how, this emblem tells of how the bee—having collected her fill of nectar, but unable to leave well enough alone—becomes trapped in a tulip when, at day’s end, its petals close around her. The bee works furiously to escape; a snail, similarly caught, falls asleep without a struggle. In the morning, when the petals reopen, the snail simply leaves, while the bee dies of exhaustion. Pulter sees in her garden an all-female community of vegetable, animal, and celestial beings demonstrating the moral which the poem then shows men to have enacted historically, in a sequence of exemplars warning against impatience and fighting fate. While that may be the overall moral, the poem also touches on the tension between confinement and freedom which so often preoccupies Pulter. The framing phrase for the emblem’s moral—“if no hope of liberty you see”—closely tracks the concluding declaration in “Why Must I Thus Forever Be Confined” (Poem 57): “I no liberty expect to see …” Did Pulter identify with the snail or the bee?

app.rdg: When fair Aurora drest with Raidient Light
When fair Auroragoddess of dawn, dressed with radiant light,
Had triumph’d o’re the Gloomey Shades of Night
Had triumphed o’er the gloomy shades of night–
When Shee her Virgin beavty first diſcloſes
When she her virginpure beauty first discloses,
Her dewey Curles Stuck full of half blown Roſes
Her dewy curls stuck full of half-blownhalf-blossomed roses,
Lapt in A Robe of Silver mixt with graie
Lappedwrapped up in a robe of silver mixed with gray,
Which did prognoſticate a glorious day
Which did prognosticateforetell a glorious day–
Out flew the active Amizonian Maid
Out flew the active Amazonian maidAmazons were legendary female warriors who served a queen; here used figuratively to describe a bee;
The Hills and Dales, not onely Shee Surveyd
The hills and dales not only she surveyed,
But out of every Gold Enameld“E” and “e” appear written over earlier “i”s Cup
But out of every gold-enamelled cup
Her Mornings draught of Nectar Shee did Sup
Her morning’s draught of nectar she did sup.
Nay where the Toad, and Spider poyſons found
Nay, where the toad and spider’s poison found
Mell Shee Extracts, for this ^ her Wisdome’s Crownd
Mellhoney she extracts; for this her wisdom’s crownedBees were reputed to be able to turn poisons into honey..
On Nightſhade“t” in different hand from main scribe, Henbane, Helliſh Acconite
On nightshade, henbane, hellish aconite,
On Opium, Hemlock, Shee doth Safely lite
On opium, hemlockThis plant, like opium and the three in the previous line, are all poisonous. she doth safely lightland.
Thus being with choyce Extractions loaded well
Thus being with choice extractions loaded well,
Shee turn’d to flie to her Sexanguler Cell
She turned to fly to her sexangularsix-sided cell.
But takeing of my Garden in her way
But taking ofapprehending my garden in her way,
Though full before Shee could not chooſe but Stay
Though full before, she could not choose but stay
To See the \ curious \insertion in different hand from main scribe Ouricolas curiousdouble strike-through drest
To see the curiousclever, elaborately made auriculastype of flower dressed
More variously then Iris dewey breast
More variously than Iris’sgoddess of the rainbow, also a flower dewy breast.
Then were my Tulips painted in there Pride
Then were my tulips painted in their pride,
Which when this covetous Inſect Eſpi’de
Which, when this covetous insect espied,
To carry home her wealth Shee’d not ye power
To carry home her wealth she’d not the power
Till Shee had Search’d the Sweets of every &ff;lower
Till she had searched the sweets of every flower.
The Sun, from home, all, Influence Receives
The sun, from whom all influence receives“whom” is spelled as “home” in the manuscript; all are influenced by the sun,
Bid them decline, The Tulip cloſ’d her Leaves
Bids them declinebend down, droop; the tulip closed her leavespetals,
And in that painted Priſon Shut the Bee
And in that painted prison shut the bee,
With her A Snail, who Slid about to See
Withand with her a snail, who slid about (to see
Where to get out upon her Unctious brest
Where to get out) upon her unctuousgreasy breast;
But Seeing noe hope, Shee laid her down to rest
But seeing no hope, she laid herherself down to rest,
Whilst the Angrie Bee dothdouble strike-through \did \in different hand from main scribe Such A &ff;luttring Keep
Whilst the angry bee did such a flutt’ring keepmake,
Shee nor her fellow Priſner could not Sleep
SheNeither she nor her fellow pris’ner could not sleep.
But Night being past, Delia diffuſ’d his Rais
But night being past, Deliahere, Apollo, the sun god (named because he was from the island of Delos, usually called Delius) diffused his rays;
The Tulip then her gilded Leaves diſplais
The tulip then her gilded leaves displays.
Out Slid the Snail, the Bee did fainting lie
Out slid the snail; the bee did fainting lie
And thus with Beating of her Self did die
And thus with beating of herself did die.
Then let impatient Spirits here but See
Then let impatient spirits here but see
What ’tis to Struggle with their destinie
What ’tis to struggle with their destiny.
Soe Stout Byrone in Priſon was inrag’d

So stoutproud, arrogant BironCharles de Gontant, duc de Biron; a celebrated sixteenth-century French soldier famed for his overweening pride and eventually executed for treason; in George Chapman’s play about him, The Conspiracy and Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron, Biron’s sword is confiscated by the king. in prison was enraged,
Knowing his King was to his Sword ingag’d
Knowing his king was to his sword engaged.
When Bellizarus by A dog was led
When Belisariussuccessful general of sixth-century Roman emperor Justinian, later accused of conspiracy; reputedly, his eyes were put out and he ended his life as a beggar. by a dog was led,
Being blind hee patiently did beg his Bread
Being blind, he patiently did beg his bread.
Soe miſcre’nt Bajazet did Shew his Rage

So miscre’ntvillainous Bajazethfourteenth-century Turkish Emperor captured in war by Tamburlaine (the “proud Tartar”); in Christopher Marlowe’s play, Tamburlaine, Bajazeth kills himself on the bars of his prison. did show his rage
When that proud Tarter put him in A Cage
When that proud Tartar put him in a cage;
Scorning to bee A footstool to his Pride
Scorning to be a footstool to his pride,
Hee daſh’d his Curſed Brains about & died
He dashed his curséd brains about and died.
When wiſe Calistines uſ’d with greater Scorn

When wise Callistheneshistorian for Alexander the Great, reported by some to have been dismembered and displayed in a cage by Alexander in retribution for his criticisms; see Justin, Epitome of The Philippic History of Pompeius Trogus, used with greater scorn,
Tyrannically mangled Soe was Born
Tyrannically mangled, soso it was borneendured,
Hee being unmov’d Shew’d his Philoſophy
He, being unmoved, showed his philosophy:
T’is Valianter by far to live then die
’Tis valianter by far to live than die.
Then if noe hope ofimperfectly erased ascender follows Liberty you See
Then if no hope of liberty you see
Think on the Snail, the Tulip and the Beeremainder of page blank, as is reverse
Think on the snail, the tulip, and the bee.
